entry.title: Ledger in Management Accounting in S/4HANA public cloud
entry.content:
In this blog we will explain the impact of the Universal Journal’s ledger concept on controlling/ cost management. In particular the options for parallel valuation including universal parallel accounting (UPA) and the group valuation ledger. Addiiotnal we will explain the usage of extension ledgers for management purposes.

enjoy
Birgit Öttinger and  Stefan Walz

 

The Universal Journal - Basics

The Universal Journal is for sure the key innovation driver for accounting and controlling in S/4HANA. The integration of Legal and Management Reporting allows a drastic simplification in management accounting, reduces period-end activities, and at the same time enables new functionalities and completely new, fascinating reporting insights. As an example, you can check out the new project accounting and service management functionality

Figure1: Universal Journal - Integration of accounting applications

The Universal Journal offers a comprehensive perspective on your external accounting through General Ledger Accounting. Furthermore, it facilitates Management Reporting and Controlling. Management Reporting and Controlling, Market segment reporting (margin analysis), profit center and revenue recognition data are seamlessly integrated with General Ledger Accounting and consolidated into a single source of truth: the Universal Journal.

Parallel Accounting utilizing Parallel Ledgers

With the Universal Journal, parallel ledgers are available to calculate and store different amounts for financial transactions according to various accounting principles, such as IFRS (International Financial Reporting Standards) and local GAAP

One example is event-based revenue recognition using a cost based POC method in the IFRS ledger and a completed contract method in the local ledger.

In public cloud in the past, parallel valuation for cost management was limited in the sense that cost management only worked with one valuation approach: the value from the leading ledger was adopted for all parallel standard ledgers. With Universal Parallel Accounting parallel valuation in cost management, asset management, and materials management is possible: the values can be defined per ledger. UPA is always active in SAP Cloud ERP (public edition) and can be activated in SAP Cloud ERP Private (on premise) using a business function.

Here some examples for different valuation per ledger, which have an impact on controlling/ cost management:

  • You can define ledger-dependent cost rates for time confirmation and activities.
  • Controlling allocations like universal allocation, settlement or overhead calculation take the posted amounts per ledger into account. For example, there can be different asset depreciation expenses per ledger posted on a cost center. The subsequent cost center allocation allocates different amounts per ledger, ensuring that the cost center balances to zero in all ledgers.
  • You can maintain settlement rules that are ledger dependent. For example, in ledger A, you can activate the costs and settle to fixed asset—while in ledger B, you cannot activate, and instead, you settle to a cost center.
  • In the material ledger, you can maintain ledger-dependent material prices, which lead to different costs of goods sold (COGS) or material consumption costs per ledger.

This ledger-dependent valuation enables you to get a parallel value flow per ledger.

 An additional advantage of universal parallel accounting: It supports different fiscal year variants within one controlling area or even for one company code. Without universal parallel accounting, the customer is forced to define multiple controlling areas if different fiscal year variants are needed. This significantly restricts the group value flow.

Note: All fiscal year variants used need to have identic start and end dates (e.g. a fiscal period is always equal to a month).

It is not possible to create new additional ledgers for existing company codes. You cannot add or remove ledgers after scoping is completed.  All standard ledgers must be fixed before go live.

It is not recommended to proactively activate an additional ledger to cover special reporting requirements and do not take care of this parallel ledger. E.g. do not regularly perform closing. You need to close the period in all standard ledgers.

The leading ledger

One ledger must be defined as leading ledger.
SAP delivers as default the leading ledger 0L. This ledger is assigned to all company codes.

In the leading ledger all company codes must use the same fiscal year variant.

Only the leading ledger is known in logistic applications.
Examples:

  • T&E project billing reads only from leading ledger
  • cost and revenue reporting in CPM and service management read from leading ledger only
  • plan data for service orders and projects is only updated in the leading ledger

The leading ledger is the base for consolidation/ group reporting.

 

The extension ledger

With the integration of legal and management reporting, many innovations and new reporting insights are possible, but new approaches are needed to account for management-specific assessments and management specific data. For example, the representation for alternative and additional costs, or commitments and order entry data.

For this purpose, we introduced the extension ledger. Extension ledgers store management accounting data only and have no impact on legal reporting.
An extension ledger must be assigned to a standard ledger: while the standard ledger contains journal entries for all business transactions for legal and management accounting purposes, the extension ledger contains management accounting relevant journal entries only. The extension ledger only stores delta entries to the underlying standard ledger. This setup assumes that all postings in the underlying standard ledger are part of the extension ledger reporting. With this redundant data storage is avoided.

Two different ledger types are available for extension ledgers:

  • The management accounting ledger, which is used to post additional costs like statistical sales conditions and manual adjustment postings. In public cloud ledger 0C is created by default. Examples can be found in the following blog post: margin analysis 4 Sell from stock
  • The commitment ledger is used to update e.g., order entries or purchase order commitments. In public cloud ledger 0E is created by default.

You can post management adjustments directly in the management accounting extension ledger 0C with no update in a legal standard ledger as these postings are not relevant for legal reporting.
When you run a report for an extension ledger, the journal entries of the extension ledger and the underlying standard ledger are always displayed aggregated.

In public cloud default setup, extension ledgers are assigned to the leading ledger
-> 0E / 0C delivered via best practice content
A SSCUI allows customers to create additional extension ledgers assigned to any underlying ledger (SSCUI: Define Extension Ledger (103265))

Ledger setup from controlling perspective

The conditions above could lead to the following ledger setup:

Figure 2: ledger setup example

The leading ledger is equal in all company codes. It uses the same accounting principle (IFRS), and the same fiscal year variant (K4). The EBRR method for customer projects is defined as cost-based POC.
The extension ledgers 0E and 0C are assigned to the leading ledger 0L. With this setup, management reporting is mainly done in the leading ledger 0L.
The parallel ledger 2L is differently configured for both company codes: there are different local GAAPs and fiscal year variants assigned. Based on the different accounting principles assigned, different revenue recognition methods could be used for customer projects.

SAP recommends – in deviation to the delivered standard configuration - to use the leading ledger with a corporate accounting principle and one of the non-leading ledgers for the local accounting principle.

 

To enable controlling across multiple companies, you should consider the leading ledger as the main ledger for management reporting because of the following reasons:

  • The leading ledger uses the same valuation approach across all company codes. Recommendation is to assign the corporate accounting principle (typically IFRS or USGAAP).
  • Additionally, the leading ledger should use the same fiscal year variant (FYV) for all company codes, this simplifies company code comparisons.
  • Extension ledgers are assigned to the leading ledger.
  • Plan data for logistic objects like service documents or projects is only updated in the leading ledger.
  • Some revenue recognition functionality and URR is per default only active for IFRS or USGAAP – like e.g. revenue allocation between performance obligations. You will not allocate revenue in a local GAAP like HGB! This has impact on tax calculations.
    Our assumption is, that revenue allocation should impact margin analysis. Thus, management accounting should be done with IFRS/ USGAAP accounting principles, if revenue allocation is used.
    Example for revenue allocation: you sell a mobile for 1€ together with a 24 month contract. The standalone selling price is 1000€. IFRS revenue allocation would allocate revenue from the contract to the mobile. Therefore, the realized revenue for the mobile would be higher than the 1€ billed.

If more than one ledger is used, country specific accounting principles shall be assigned to a non-leading ledger (in this case the standard settings deployed during scope must be changed > ledger switch). With this, the accounting principles assigned in the non-leading ledger can be different for different company codes. Alternative FYV can be assigned per company code.

 This also aligns with the guidance from legal perspective - see here

  • SAP help Ledger Scenarios: Choosing the Right Combination for Your Business Needs 
  • KBA Assigning Accounting Principles to Ledgers and Company Codes in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 
  • community article ledger-configuration 

Group Valuation Ledger

 Purpose

The group valuation ledger aims to eliminate profit and margins for intercompany processes on transaction level. With this, intercompany processes are evaluated on a cost only basis. This enables basic functionality for market segment reporting from a group perspective. Especially group costs for multi-step production processes in several company codes can be analyzed.

It is not recommended to use the group valuation ledger as a basis for consolidation. Consolidation should be based on the leading ledger.

 

Technical Conditions

The Group Valuation ledger 4G in public cloud, can only be added during initial scoping with scope item 5W2, a deletion is not supported.

The supported scope is listed in the SAP note 3100892 and SAP note 3093830 and will be activated with the activation of the scope item.

It is recommended to use the same accounting principle in 4G and in the leading ledger. The group ledger should be referenced to the leading ledger – one ledger group.

Closing must run in 4G as in all standard ledgers.

supported scope with CE 2602

First focus was on intercompany stock transfer scenarios. As mentioned in note 3100892 not all intercompany stock transfer scenarios are supported with ledger 4G. E.g. returns, sales BOMs, and subcontracting are not supported.

Intercompany sales processes and especially intercompany service processes do not support a proper group view (no revenue and margin elimination).

For intercompany activity allocations/ time confirmations the intercompany margin is not posted in the group valuation ledger.

 

Different approaches for group reporting and group valuation ledger

Although group valuation ledger and group reporting ultimately serve consolidation purposes, there are differences:

Group valuation ledger (Ledger 4G) targets a real-time, transaction-based management perspective by eliminating intercompany profits between individual trading partners. Supporting management decisions along the end-to-end value chain – for one special ICO sales process only, whereas

Group reporting is used to fulfill the legally required consolidation process including the period-end closing according to the relevant accounting standard. For this in group reporting a separate consolidation ledger for all closing and reporting steps is used.

entry.title: User validation error due to mandatory Event Reason for Job Information from the 2H 2025 release.
entry.content:
Hello team,

As you know, starting with the 2H 2025 Release, the Event Reason field is now mandatory for the ONB-RCM integration. If it is not mapped, this change will trigger a business process error, preventing the candidate from moving from ONB to RCM
 
There are several blogs and KBAs that explain how to address/prevent this issue, either by creating a business rule or by using the Recruit-to-Hire Data Mapping tool (0003205529, 3232848, 0003671856 ). 
 
After analyzing the available options, we decided to map it using the Recruit-to-Hire Data Mapping tool. However, even after implementing this solution, we are still facing issues in our test environment, so I hope someone here can help us address them.
 
As mentioned in the notes I shared earlier, I created a custom picklist field in each existing job requisition, using external code values identical to the existing hire event external codes in EC.
Event reason custom field in job requisition
 
 

Matching picklist used for job requisition custom field

Then, I mapped the corresponding field in JobInfo

 

After doing all that, it is supposed to fix the mandatory event reason issue but we keep getting the following error:

I got a JSON Output response to check the values passed from recruiting to onboarding and it looks like this 

 
It seems that the event reason value is being passed correctly; however, even after restarting the process from BPE, the issue persists. As a result, the onboardee remains stuck with a data validation error and does not appear in the ONB dashboard

 For context:

  1. I have tested with multiple candidates in different job Reqs and the behavior is the same, 
  2. The event-reason standard field wasn't created in manage business configuration so I created it recently (I don't know how ONB worked before that)
I’m sharing my experience with this configuration to get any suggestions, as I honestly don’t understand what’s happening here

I already opened a SAP Support ticket, if I receive a solution or an explication, I'll share it later.

entry.title: Re: Impact of Employee Central on Performance and Goals M...
entry.content:
Based on my experience with SAP SuccessFactors, here are some key points and potential impacts to consider when introducing Employee Central (EC) alongside an existing Talent suite:

  1. Job Structure

    • With EC, the Job Codes /Job Classifications will likely become the master data for your Talent processes. Any misalignment between EC and the Talent module can impact competencies

    • It’s important to review mappings between EC Job Codes and competencies ( and maybe Skills) to ensure that performance, succession, and development plans functions correctly.

  2. Position Management

    • If you are using positions  EC will now control the position hierarchy. Vacant manager positions can affect routemaps, talent reviews.

    • Validate that position hierarchies are correct in EC and check for any changes in reporting lines that could affect talent processes, for example if the position of a manager becomes empty what will happen to performance forms (?).

  3. Job Relationships and Performance Route Maps

    • Talent modules often rely on job relationships for routing and notifications.

    • With EC, these relationships may be updated automatically via position , which could change existing performance route maps or calibration groupings. It’s important to test all routing scenarios before going live.

  4. Additional considerations

    • Ensure integration points (data sync, replication to Talent modules) are tested thoroughly.

    • Review defaulting rules in Performance, Succession, and Career modules, as they may pull new EC data differently.

Bottom line: EC becomes the master for core HR data, so the main impact will be around how Talent modules read job, position, and reporting information.
Thorough testing of route maps, calibration groups, and competency mappings is critical to avoid disruption.

entry.title: SAP for Me – Adoption Report – Drive More Business Value Realization
entry.content:
This blog is a continuation of my previous blog, Drive more Business Value out of your SAP Public Cloud Solution Subscriptions.

However, in this blog, I want to focus on the Adoption Report included in SAP for Me – Customer Insights as a quick way to understand opportunities for Business Value Realization.

But first, I would like to refer you to the blog SAP Adoption PDF Report generator in Customer Insights (in SAP for Me), written by my SAP colleague Jose Seren, to understand the overall report structure.

Now, similar to my previous blog, if you are an SAP Public Cloud customer running solutions like SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, SAP SuccessFactors, SAP Ariba, etc., or you are a new SAP Business Suite customer running public cloud packages, this report can help you to understand areas of unrealized business value in your integrated system landscape.

While the report is very comprehensive, I only would like to focus on the Business Value Realization section, because it is here where you can see quick wins on value realization by focusing on value drivers for which you currently have no solution capabilities in use or low usage.

Let's look at the following example.

Business Value Realization Overview by Solution Area

In this example, this SAP customer is running several public cloud solutions including SAP Business Data Cloud, SAP SuccessFactors (Core HR and Payroll, Learning and Talent), SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, several SAP Procurement solutions (Ariba Buying and Invoicing, Ariba Sourcing, Ariba Central Invoice Management, etc.), and some SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition add-ons like Cash & Treasury, Multi-Bank Connectivity, and Group Reporting.

Now, the graphic below shows the total number of value drivers that have solution capabilities in use per solution area. For instance, if I look at SAP Business Data Cloud, the report indicates that out of 10 value drivers our customer is only using solution capabilities that impact 5 value drivers—so this means that there are great opportunities to bring more business value to this solution and impact the other 5 value drivers.

Business Value Realization Overview by Solution Area – Value Drivers with used and unused solution capabilities

Now, if we drill down in the report for SAP Business Data Cloud, the report presents to me the value drivers that currently have unused solution capabilities, which I can analyze to bring more business value to this solution area.

Detailed Business Value Realization – Business Data Cloud - Value Drivers with used and unused solution capabilities

As you can see from the report, I have an opportunity to start using solution capabilities that can impact these five value drivers.

Let me focus on the value driver “Reduce data management cost” in SAP Business Data Cloud—the report itself includes the solution capabilities that I can start activating to bring more business value. You can find them at the end of the Adoption Report under “Unrealized Business Value by Solution Area.”

Unrealized Business Value – Value drivers that can impact business outcomes by activating solution capability not used

As you can see from the graphic, the customer could activate “Analytics Cataloging” solution capability to impact the value driver “reduce data management cost.” However, you can see that this solution capability will also impact other value drivers, including increase user confidence in data and improve analytics FTE productivity.

Unrealized Business Value – Value drivers that can impact business outcomes by activating solution capability not used

As you can see from the graphic, the customer could activate “Story Extensibility” solution capability to impact the value driver “reduce data management cost.” However, you can see that this solution capability will also impact other value drivers, including: reduce data integration cost and improve analytics FTE productivity.

As you can see, the report provides a very fast overview of unrealized business value. Alternatively to the report, and to explore the value drivers, solution capabilities, and opportunities to realize more business value, you can use the Cloud Functional Usage – Business Value section in SAP for Me, as I explained in my previous blog.

SAP for Me - Cloud Functional Usage – Business Value

I hope this Adoption Report included in SAP for Me provides you with some ideas to bring more business outcomes for your entire public cloud landscape.

Keep in mind that solution capabilities are expanding from traditional functional scope to also include SAP Business AI, so SAP will continue to add more in this area.

Remember, this is not the only tool that can be used; SAP has other tools such as SAP Signavio, SAP WalkMe, SAP LeanIX, and SAP Cloud ALM that can be used in tandem to help drive more business value from your SAP subscription. I encourage you to discuss these points with your SAP Customer Success Manager, SAP Account Executive, or SAP Partner. They may be able to provide you with additional recommendations and guidance.

Your insights and opinions are valuable, so please don't hesitate to contribute by commenting on this blog.

Follow us via @SAP and #S4HANA or follow @Marco_Valencia (SAP Business Suite Customer Success Management).

entry.title: Re: Programmatically create and retrieve documents attached in GOS (Generic Object Services) via Sto
entry.content:
Excellent and very useful blog, thanks for sharing 👍

Just to add for readers:
• GOS attachments are typically stored via ArchiveLink and linked using SRGBTBREL (RELTYPE = ‘ATTA’)
• ARCHIVOBJECT_CREATE_FILE can work with presentation server or application server paths, but logical file names (e.g. ARCHIVLINK_FILE_READ) must be properly maintained via FILE transaction
• For background jobs or UI5 scenarios, converting content using SCMS_BINARY_TO_XSTRING and handling files on the app server is the recommended approach

This approach works well for ECC as well as S/4HANA systems using content servers like SAP Content Server or OpenText.
